Mutual Administrative Assistance in Customs\nMatters in Annex E.\nArticle 38 \nCustoms\nlegislation and procedures \n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall do\neverything in their power to ensure that their respective trade and customs\nlaws, provisions and procedures are based on: \na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the international instruments and\nstandards in force in customs and trade areas, including the essential elements\nof the International Convention on the Simplification and Harmonisation of\nCustoms Procedures (revised Kyoto Convention), the World Customs Organisation\n(WCO) Framework of Standards to Secure and Facilitate Global Trade, the WCO\nCustoms Data Model and the International Convention on the Harmonised Commodity\nDescription and Coding System (HS);\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the use of a single administrative\ndocument or electronic equivalent in order to make import and export customs\ndeclarations;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 regulations to avoid unnecessary and\ndiscriminatory measures for economic operations, protect against fraud and\nprovide additional facilities for operators displaying a high level of\ncompliance with customs legislation;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the use of modern customs techniques,\nincluding risk assessment, simplified procedures for the entry and release of\ngoods, post release controls and enterprise audit methods; \ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the progressive development of\nsystems, including those based upon Information Technology, to facilitate the\nelectronic exchange of data between economic operators, customs administrations\nand other related agencies;\nf)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a system of binding customs\ninformation, in particular regarding tariff classification and rules of origin\nin conformity with the rules provided for in the legislation of each\nParty, in so far as the customs services have all the information they\nconsider necessary;\ng)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 rules relating to penalties for infringements\nof customs regulations or procedural requirements that are proportionate and\nnon-discriminatory and the application of which will not give rise to undue\ndelay;\nh)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 transparent, non-discriminatory and\nproportionate rules in respect of the licensing of customs agents. The Parties\nrecognise the interest in the future elimination of any obligation to use the\nservices of customs agents. The Parties shall broach this question within the\nSpecial Customs and Facilitation of Trade Committee;\ni)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 observance of the provisions of the\nWTO Agreement on Preshipment Inspection. The Parties recognise the interest in\nthe future elimination of all requirements for the performance of compulsory\ninspections prior to the dispatch of goods or on reaching their destination. The\nParties shall broach this question within the Special Customs and Facilitation\nof Trade Committee.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In order to improve\nworking methods and ensure respect for the principles of non-discrimination,\ntransparency and efficiency, the Parties shall:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 take the measures necessary to reduce,\nsimplify and standardise the data and documents required by customs and other\nrelated bodies;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 simplify customs requirements and\nformalities wherever possible, in respect of the rapid release and clearance of\ngoods;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ensure effective, prompt,\nnon-discriminatory and accessible procedures for applicants to secure a right\nof appeal against customs administrative actions and other decisions affecting\nimports, exports or goods in transit. \nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ensure the maintenance of ethical\nstandards through the application of measures reflecting the principles of the\nrelevant international conventions and instruments in this area, in particular\nthe revised Arusha Declaration of 2003.\nArticle 39\nFacilitation\nof transit movements\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall ensure\nthe free transit of goods through their territory on the most suitable transit\nroute. Any restrictions, controls or requirements in this regard must be\njustified by a legitimate public policy objective, and must be non-discriminatory,\nproportionate and applied in a uniform manner.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Without prejudice to\nlegitimate customs checks, the Parties shall treat goods in transit from the\nterritory of the other Party no less favourably than goods from the domestic\nmarket, exports, imports and their movement.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall\nestablish transit customs regimes to allow the movement of goods with no\nobligation to pay customs duties or other charges, subject to the provision of\nappropriate guarantees.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall\nendeavour to promote and implement regional transit arrangements with the aim\nof reducing barriers to trade.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall use\ninternational standards and instruments arising from the transit of goods.\n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall ensure\nthe cooperation and coordination of all the relevant authorities in their\nterritories in order to facilitate transit traffic and promote cross-border\ncooperation.\nArticle 40 \nRelations\nwith the business community\nThe Parties agree:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to ensure that all the\nlegislation, procedures, fees and charges can be published by appropriate means\nand where possible by electronic means;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to encourage cooperation between\nthe operators and the relevant administrative authorities through the use of\nnon-arbitrary, publicly accessible procedures such as the Protocols of\nAgreement based on those promulgated by the WCO;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to ensure that their respective\ncustoms and related regimes and the requirements and procedures associated with\nthem continue to meet the needs of the business community, are in line with\nbest practices and remain as unrestrictive as possible for trade;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 on the need for consultation with\ntrade representatives in due time and on a regular basis regarding legislative\nproposals and procedures relating to customs and trade issues. To this end,\nappropriate and regular mechanisms for consultation between the administrative\nauthorities and the business community shall be established by each Party;\ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that a sufficient period of time\nmust pass between the publication and the entry into force of any new or\namended laws, procedures, rights or charges; The Parties shall publish\nadministrative information concerning in particular agency requirements, entry\nprocedures, working hours and operational procedures of the customs authorities\nin ports and at border posts, and also on information contact points;\nArticle 41 \nCustoms\nvalue\nThe WTO Agreement on Implementation of\nArticle VII of GATT 1994 shall govern the application of the customs value to\ntrade between the Parties. The Parties shall cooperate with a view to taking a\ncommon approach to issues relating to customs value.\nArticle 42 \nRegional\nintegration in the West African region\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties agree to push\nforward customs reforms, in particular the harmonisation of procedures and\nregulation in order to facilitate trade in the West African region.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the above purposes,\nthe Parties shall organise close cooperation of all the bodies concerned by\napplying the relevant international customs rules.\nArticle 43 \nCooperation\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise the\nimportance of cooperation on customs and trade facilitation for the\nimplementation of this Agreement. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In accordance with\nparagraph 6, Annex D to the Decision of the WTO General Council of 1 August\n2004 and, subject to the provisions contained in Part III, the Parties agree to\nset up appropriate technical and financial programmes of assistance to make it\npossible to implement the provisions of this Chapter, in particular concerning:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the development of appropriate,\nsimplified legislative and regulatory provisions; \nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 information and awareness-raising\naimed at operators, including training for the staff concerned;;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 building up capacities, modernisation\nand connectivity between customs authorities and related services. \nArticle 44 \nTransitional\nmeasures\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognize the\nneed for transitional measures to ensure the smooth implementation of the\nprovisions of this Chapter.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Without prejudice to its\ncommitments under the WTO, the West Africa Party shall be granted a\ntransitional period of five (5) years starting from the entry into force of\nthis Agreement in which to comply with the obligations provided for in Article\n38(1)(b) and (d). This period may be reviewed depending on the results of the\nreforms to be effected by the West African region in cooperation with the\nEuropean Union.\nArticle 45 \nSpecial\nCommittee on Customs and Trade Facilitation\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall\nestablish a Special Committee on Customs and Trade Facilitation, which shall be\nmade up of representatives of the Parties.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The functions of the\nSpecial Committee on Customs and Trade Facilitation shall be as follows:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to ensure that the implementation and\nmanagement of this Chapter, the Protocol on rules of origin and the Protocol on\nmutual administrative assistance are monitored;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to act as a consultation and\ndiscussion forum for all matters relating to customs, in particular customs\nregimes and customs clearance procedures, rules of origin, customs value,\ntariff classification, customs cooperation and mutual administrative assistance;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to develop cooperation for the\ndrawing- up, implementation and monitoring of customs regimes and customs\nclearance procedures, rules of origin and mutual administrative assistance.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Special Committee on\nCustoms and Trade Facilitation shall meet once a year, on a date and with an\nagenda to be agreed in advance by the Parties. The Parties may decide to call\nad hoc meetings of the Committee if necessary.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Special Committee on\nCustoms and Trade Facilitation shall be chaired alternatively by each Party.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Special Committee on\nCustoms and Trade Facilitation shall report to the Joint Implementation\nCommittee of the EPA. \nCHAPTER 6\nAGRICULTURE,\nFISHERIES AND FOOD SECURITY\nArticle 46 \nObjectives\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise that\nin the West African region, the agriculture, including livestock farming, and\nfisheries sectors account for a significant proportion of GDP, play a key role\nin the fight against food insecurity and provide an income and employment for\nmost of the working population.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This Agreement, through\nits economic and trade effects, and actions in connection with the West Africa\nEPA Development Programme, should help to increase productivity,\ncompetitiveness and diversity of output in the agriculture and fisheries\nsectors. It should also facilitate the development of the processing sector and\nincrease trade in agricultural, food and fisheries products between the Parties\nin a way that is consistent with the sustainable development of natural\nresources.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise the\nas yet unexploited potential of the West African region and the need to support\nthe implementation of its national and regional policies in connection with the\ncooperation policies implemented by both Parties in line with the provisions\ncontained in Part III of this Agreement.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise that\nfisheries, biological and maritime resources are of great interest to the\nEuropean Union and the West African region and that the real risk of stock\nexhaustion, in particular as a result of industrial fishing, make it necessary\nfor them to promote the sustainable management of fish and aquatic resources. \n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties also recognise\nthat the fisheries and marine ecosystems of the West African States are\ncomplex, biologically diverse and fragile and that the way in which they are\nexploited must take account of this through conservation and the sustainable\nand efficient management of fisheries and the associated ecosystems on the\nbasis of scientific advice and the precautionary principle defined by the Code\nof Conduct of the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations\nfor responsible fisheries practices.\n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties also recognise\nthe economic and social importance of activities relating to fisheries and the\nutilisation of the living marine resources of the West African States and the need to maximise their contribution to food security, employment, reducing\npoverty, increasing income and the social stability of fishing communities.\n7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise that\nsecuring the food security of the population and raising the means of\nsubsistence in a rural environment are essential for reducing poverty and must\nbe viewed in the wider context of sustainable development and the Millennium\nDevelopment Goals. They therefore agree to work together to avoid any breakdown\nin the agricultural and food products markets in West Africa. \n8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union\nundertakes to help the countries of West Africa to develop an effective\nMonitoring/Control/Surveillance (MCS) system for fisheries as part of its\npolicies, including fisheries policy. \n9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties also agree on\nthe importance for the region of establishing policies that will make it\npossible to increase the benefits from fisheries to the people of the West\nAfrican region.\n10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the purpose of achieving\nthe objectives referred to in this Article, the Parties take full account of\nthe diversity of characteristics and economic, social and environmental needs\nand the development strategies of the West Africa Party.\nArticle 47 \nFood security\nWhen the implementation\nof this Agreement results or seems likely to result in difficulties for the\nWest Africa Party or a State of the West African region in obtaining or gaining\naccess to the products necessary for ensuring food security, the West Africa\nParty or the State in the West African region may take appropriate measures in\nline with the procedures described in Article 22.\nArticle 48 \nCooperation in the areas of agriculture and food security\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Cooperation with regard to\nagriculture and food security is covered by Articles 53 and 69 of the Cotonou\nAgreement. The Parties agree that the provisions of the Cotonou Agreement\nrelating to this Chapter and Agreement shall be implemented in a complementary\nmanner through mutual reinforcement.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To enable the countries of\nthe West African region to ensure the food security of their people and promote\nviable and sustainable agriculture, both Parties shall examine all the\ncooperation measures in accordance with the provisions of Part III, with a\nview, in particular, to:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 promoting the performance of\nirrigation and water management programmes;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 promoting technological progress,\ninnovation and diversification in the agricultural sector;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 popularising the use of agricultural\ninputs that are environmentally friendly;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 developing research with a view to the\nproduction of improved seeds and their use by farming communities;\ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 developing an integrated agricultural\nand livestock farming system;\nf)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 improving the storage and\npreservation of agricultural products;\ng)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 reinforcing the role of the State as a\nsupporter and adviser of private operators;\nh)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 strengthening the agricultural\nsectors;\ni)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 managing tracks and roads serving\nrural communities to enhance the collection and movement of agricultural\nproducts;\n(j)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 contributing to improving warning\nsystems to prevent crises; \n(k)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 contributing to the development of\nregional exchanges for greater centralisation of information regarding the\nregional availability of food products;\n(l)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 promoting contract farming with\npartners from the European Union to supply organic products, for example; \n(m)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 identifying new opportunities for the\ndevelopment and export of products for which there is a strong international\ndemand;\n(n)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 promoting land law reforms to increase\nthe legal certainty of farmers and in so doing promote the development of\nefficient agriculture and raise credit to encourage private investment in the\nagricultural sector. \n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties agree that\nspecial situations of food scarcity might necessitate the performance of\nspecific ad hoc food aid programmes to help countries facing these situations.\nHowever, such programmes should not in any way pose a threat to the food\nsecurity policies in force in the States receiving such aid.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To limit any harmful\neffects of the import of food aid into the West African region, both Parties\nundertake to favour triangular food aid arrangements that promote trading in\nlocal agricultural products. \n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties emphasise the\nimportance of the agricultural sector in the economy and for food security in West Africa and, in particular, the sensitive nature of the sectors that depend on\ninternational markets. Each Party shall ensure transparency in its domestic\nsupport policies and measures. The European Union shall therefore send, by any\nappropriate means, regular reports to West Africa on such measures, including,\nin particular, the legal basis, the forms of measures and the associated sums.\nThe Parties may exchange information concerning any agricultural policy measure\nat the request of either of the Parties.\n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union Party\nundertakes to refrain from the use of export subsidies for agricultural\nproducts exported to West Africa.\n7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With a view to\nimplementing cooperation with regard to agriculture and food security, the\nParties shall set up an arrangement for continuous dialogue concerning the\nareas referred to in this Article. The terms of this dialogue shall be\nspecified by mutual agreement between the Parties.\nArticle 49\nFisheries cooperation\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With a view to developing\nand promoting cooperation with regard to fisheries, in accordance with the\nprovisions contained in Part III, the Parties undertake to:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 collaborate with a view to sustainable\ndevelopment of the fish resources of the West African region and apply the\nprecautionary principle when determining the sustainable level of catches and\ndefining the conditions for access to fish resources that must be observed to\navoid overexploitation of stocks and any negative impact on the environment and\nthe ecosystem;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 promote the improvement of the supply\ncapacity and competitiveness of fishery products. The European Union therefore\nundertakes to help the Member States of the region to meet the needs arising\nfrom the application of sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) measures and to\ndevelop the regional market for fishery products;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 promote investment and access to\nfunding to increase the productivity of fishery enterprises in the region;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 collaborate with a view to the\nsustainable management of small-scale fisheries and the preparation and implementation\nof a policy for the development of aquaculture in West Africa;\ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 draw up and propose minimum measures\nto be observed by vessels, in order to improve the monitoring, control and\nsurveillance of their activities;\nf)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 coordinate efforts to enhance the\nmeans for preventing, discouraging and eliminating Illegal, Unreported and\nUnregulated Fishing (IUUF) and for taking appropriate measures for this\npurpose. In this regard, the Parties undertake to take any necessary measures\nto end illegal fishing and prevent its continuation, without prejudice to any\nother action they consider appropriate;\ng)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 establish a vessel monitoring system\n(VMS) for all of West Africa, with all the West African States using a\ncompatible VMS;\nh)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in addition to an obligatory compatible\nVMS, all of West Africa, together with the European Union Party, undertakes to\ndevelop other arrangements to ensure effective control and surveillance\npolicies;\ni)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 lighten traceability and\ncertification procedures and conditions for fishery products exported from the\nregion to the market of the European Union;\n(j)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 improve and reinforce fishery\ncontrol, surveillance and monitoring mechanisms and arrangements in order to\ncombat illegal, unregulated and unreported fishing, including the adoption of\nminimum measures to be observed by vessels to permit the monitoring, control\nand surveillance of their activities;\n(k)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 authorise the taking of appropriate\nprotection measures based on scientific recommendations and after having\nconsulted the various interested parties, including the European Union, if\nthere is a danger of the sustainable management of fish and aquatic resources\nof the region being compromised; \n(l)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 strengthen scientific research into\nthe state of fish resources in the West African region;\n(m)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 improve and reinforce the information\nsystem and the system for processing fishery statistics, concerning migratory\nspecies in particular;\n(n)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 strengthen cooperation in all areas of\ncommon interest with regard to fisheries.\nArticle 50\nRegional\nintegration\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise that\ngreater integration of the agricultural and food markets and sectors of the\nWest African States through the progressive elimination of the remaining\nbarriers and the adoption of an appropriate regulatory framework will help to deepen\nthe process of regional integration and achieve the objectives referred to in\nthis Chapter.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 According to the\nprovisions contained in Part III of the West Africa EPA Development Programme,\nthey shall work on the preparation and implementation of regional policies for\nthe agricultural and fisheries sectors and increase the efficiency of the\nregional markets in those \u00a0sectors. \nArticle 51 \nExchange\nof information and consultation on matters relating to agriculture and\nfisheries\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties agree to exchange\nexperience, information and best practices and to consult one another\nconcerning any area covered by the objectives of this Chapter and relevant to\ntrade between the Parties.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties agree that\nsuch a dialogue will be especially useful in the following areas in particular:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 exchange of information on\nagricultural production, consumption and trade and on the respective market\ndevelopments for agricultural and fish products;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 exchange of information on\nagriculture, rural development and fisheries policies, laws and regulations;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 discussion of policy and institutional\nchanges needed to transform the agricultural and fisheries sectors as well as\nthe formulation and implementation of regional policies on agriculture, food,\nrural development and fisheries in pursuit of regional integration;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 exchange of views on new technologies\nand quality control measures;\ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 exchange\nof views for a better understanding and monitoring of private standards in\nforce in the European Union.\nPART\nIII\nCOOPERATION\nFOR IMPLEMENTATION OF DEVELOPMENT AND ACHIEVEMENT OF THE OBJECTIVES OF THE EPA\nArticle 52 \nObjectives\n\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties undertake,\nunder this Agreement, to strengthen their cooperation and make a joint\ncommitment to implement the EPA and achieve its objectives. The European Union\nParty undertakes to support the West Africa Party to implement an EPA that is\nconducive to development.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The joint commitment by\nthe Parties is part of the vision for the development of the West African\nregion and shall contribute to the achievement of the priorities laid down in\nPart I of this Agreement. The Parties therefore agree that improving access to\nthe market of the European Union is not a sufficient condition for bringing\nabout the profitable insertion of the West African region into world trade.\nThey therefore undertake to take effective measures that should contribute to\nthe establishment in the West African region of a solid, competitive and\ndiversified economic base, the deepening of its economic integration and its adaptation\nto the new context created by this Agreement in order to benefit from the\neconomic partnership.\nArticle 53 \nPrinciples\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties agree to\nimplement cooperation intended to back up, through technical and financial\nsupport, the efforts of West Africa to meet the commitments made under this\nAgreement. The cooperation is also intended to help the West African region to\nlift the constraints that are undermining efforts to diversify and increase its\noutput, in order to increase intra-regional trade and benefit from the opening\nup of the European market. They undertake to implement the EPA Development\nProgramme (PAPED) in order to ensure the achievement of the objectives of the\nAgreement. To this end, the provisions of the Cotonou Agreement concerning\neconomic and regional cooperation and integration shall be implemented with a\nview to maximising the benefits of this Agreement.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties undertake to\nensure consistency between development cooperation and the international\ncommitments of the Parties with regard to sustainable development and regional\ndevelopment strategies.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The new trade system\nestablished by this Agreement and the commitments made with regard to\ndevelopment cooperation shall complement one another and both together\ncontribute to the development aspect of the Agreement. Under Article 2(4) of\nthis Agreement, the new trade system shall be based on reciprocity, take\naccount of the difference in the level of development and introduce special and\ndifferential treatment and progressive asymmetric liberalisation for West Africa.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties also agree\nthat the provisions of this Part cannot be interpreted as preventing the West\nAfrica Party from pursuing its growth and development objectives, implementing\nits policies and achieving its regional integration.\nArticle 54 \nFinancing\narrangements\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union\nundertakes to support the actions and projects linked to the development aspect\nof the Agreement. European Union funding[2]\nregarding development cooperation between West Africa and the European Union to\nsupport the implementation of this Agreement shall be provided through:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 appropriate rules and procedures\nprovided for by the Cotonou Agreement, in particular the programming procedures\nof the European Development Fund;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 relevant instruments financed by the\nGeneral Budget of the European Union;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 other financial arrangements to be\ncreated in the event of the expiry of the Cotonou Agreement.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Member States of the\nEuropean Union collectively undertake to support, by means of their respective\ndevelopment policies and instruments, including in connection with aid for\ntrade, development activities for regional economic cooperation and for the\nimplementation of this Agreement, at both national and regional levels, in\naccordance with the principles of effectiveness, coordination and\ncomplementarity of aid.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union and its\n Member States undertake to finance the development aspect of the Agreement for\na period at least corresponding to the time it takes West Africa to liberalise\ntrade under this Agreement, in accordance with the financial instruments, the\nlegal provisions of the Parties and the principles laid down in Article 2 of\nthis Agreement.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union and its\n Member States undertake to assist West Africa in raising additional funding\nfor the development aspect of the Agreement from other donors.\nArticle 55 \nEPA\nDevelopment Programme\nTo support the autonomous efforts of the\nregion to ensure its development, the Parties shall make the financial and\ntechnical arrangements necessary for implementation of the EPA Development\nProgramme (PAPED) and achievement of its objectives, in accordance with the\nprovisions of Article 54 above, in order to give concrete form to the\ndevelopment aspect of this Agreement. \nArticle 56\nThe\nPAPED objectives\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The EPA Development\nProgramme is part of a long-term vision for the achievement of the development\nobjectives of the Agreement. Its overall objective is to build a regional\neconomy that is competitive, harmoniously integrated with the world economy and\nstimulates growth and sustainable development. Consistency shall be established\nbetween the PAPED and the aid for trade programme for the West African region\nand regional strategies for the regional economic and sectoral development of\nthis region. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The specific objective to\nbe attained by the EPA Development Programme is to enable the West African\nregion to fully benefit from the opportunities offered by the EPA and to meet\nthe adjustment costs and face the challenges associated with implementation of\nthe Agreement.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To this end, the programme\nmust contribute to:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the achievement of rapid, sustained\neconomic growth that creates jobs and contributes to sustainable development\nand reducing poverty in the West African region;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 increasing the diversity and\ncompetitiveness of the economies of the West African region;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 increasing the population's output and\nincome;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 deepening the process of regional\nintegration and increasing intra-regional trade;\ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 increasing the market shares of the\nWest African region on the European market through such measures as improving\naccess to the said market;\nf)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 promoting investment in West Africa,\npartnership between the private sectors of the European Union and West Africa and improving the business environment in the West African region.\nArticle 57 \nThe\ngoals of PAPED\nThe areas for action covered by the EPA\nDevelopment Programme are based on five goals:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 diversifying and increasing\nproduction capacities;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 developing intra-regional trade\nand facilitating access to international markets;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 improving and reinforcing\nnational and regional infrastructures linked to trade; \nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 making essential adjustments and\ntaking account of other needs linked to trade;\ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 implementation and\nmonitoring/evaluation of the EPA by the West African region.\nArticle 58 \nPAPED\nimplementation arrangements\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The EPA Development\nProgramme is subject to a Protocol that is an integral part of the Agreement\nand is contained in Annex F. The arrangements for the implementation of this\nprogramme shall be defined in the Protocol. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The PAPED shall be\nimplemented through a matrix of activities combined with a financial\nassessment, a schedule and indicators for monitoring implementation. The matrix\nof activities shall be covered by a financial commitment by the European Union\nand its Member States to implement it, in accordance with the provisions of\nArticle 54 above. \n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The PAPED shall be subject\nto assessment at intervals agreed between the Parties. The PAPED shall be revised\nregularly on the basis of the results of its implementation and the impact of\nthe Agreement. To this end, an arrangement based on jointly defined indicators\nshall make it possible to continuously monitor implementation of the programme\nand assess its impact. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As part of the joint\nassessment referred to in paragraph 3, the Parties shall look for synergies\nbetween the rate of implementation of the commitments made by the West African\nregion and the progress made in carrying out the activities and programmes of\nthe PAPED, in particular the raising of funding for it, and in increasing the\nregion's competitiveness and production capacities. In accordance with the\nprovisions of this Agreement, in particular Article 54, the Parties shall take\nmeasures to reinforce these synergies in the Joint Council of the EPA. . .\nArticle 59\nSupport\nfor implementation of the rules \nThe Parties agree that the implementation\nof trade rules, including the areas of cooperation detailed in the various\nchapters of this Agreement, is fundamental to achieving the objectives of this\nAgreement. Cooperation in this field shall be organised in accordance with the\narrangements specified in Article 54. \nArticle 60 \nTaxation\nadjustment\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise the\nchallenges that the elimination or substantial reduction of customs duties\nprovided for in this Agreement can pose for the West African region and they\nagree to establish dialogue and cooperation in this field.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In light of the tariff\ndismantling schedule adopted by the Parties as part of this Agreement, the\nParties agree to establish in-depth dialogue on fiscal adjustment reforms and\nmeasures in order to reduce the budget deficit and ultimately ensure a balanced\nbudget for the countries of the West African region.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 West Africa undertakes to\nestablish tax reforms as part of the change in taxation resulting from\nliberalisation. The European Union undertakes to help West Africa to implement\nthese reforms. In view of these reforms, the European Union undertakes to\nprovide funding to cover the fiscal impact agreed by the Parties for the period\nof tariff dismantling.\nArticle 61 \nInstruments\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As part of the\nimplementation of the provisions of Part III of this Agreement, the Parties\nagree to establish the following instruments:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the Competitiveness Observatory;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the Regional EPA Fund.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Competitiveness\nObservatory shall be one of the instruments for monitoring and assessing\nimplementation of the Agreement. It shall have clear monitoring and assessment\nindicators for evaluating the impact of the EPA. The indicators shall be\nestablished as soon as the Agreement has been signed.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties recognise the\nusefulness of regional financing mechanisms. The Regional EPA Fund shall\nbe the main financing instrument of the EPA Development Programme. It\nshall be a preferred instrument for channelling support from the European Union\nand its Member States. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Regional EPA Fund\nshall be established by and for the region in order to channel funding at\nregional and, if necessary, national level and to effectively implement\nsupporting measures for this Agreement.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union and its\n  Member States undertake to channel their support either through financing\nmechanisms specific to the region or through those selected by the countries\nthat are signatories to this Agreement. The mechanisms shall be implemented in\naccordance with the principles of aid effectiveness outlined in the Paris\nDeclaration in order to ensure simple, efficient and rapid implementation. The\nParties may reach agreement on any other financing mechanism or arrangement.\n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The operating arrangements\nfor the two instruments referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article shall be\ndetermined by the Joint Council of the EPA.\nPART IV\nDISPUTE\nAVOIDANCE AND SETTLEMENT\nCHAPTER 1\nOBJECTIVE, SCOPE AND PARTIES\nArticle 62 \nObjective\nThe objective of this Part of the Agreement\nis to establish methods for avoiding and settling any disputes that may arise\nbetween the Parties in order to arrive at a mutually satisfactory solution. \nArticle 63 \nScope\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This Part applies to any\ndispute regarding the interpretation or application of this Agreement, subject\nto the provisions of Articles 20 and 21. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding paragraph\n1, the procedure set out in Article 98 of the Cotonou Agreement shall apply in\nthe event of disputes concerning the financing of development cooperation.\nArticle 64\nThe Parties to the dispute\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union and its\n  Member States are considered to be a single Party for the purposes of\npreventing and settling disputes arising from the application of this\nAgreement.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ECOWAS, the UEMOA and all\nthe West African States, including Mauritania, are also considered to be a\nsingle Party for the purpose of preventing and settling disputes arising from\nthe application of this Agreement.\nCHAPTER\n2\nDISPUTE AVOIDANCE: CONSULTATION AND MEDIATION\nArticle 65 \nConsultation\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall\nendeavour to settle disputes covered by Article 63 by entering into\nconsultations in good faith in order to reach a mutually satisfactory solution.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Any Party wishing to enter\ninto consultations shall do so by presenting a request in writing to the other\nParty with a copy to the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA, specifying\nthe measure in question and the provisions of the Agreement with which, in its\nopinion, the measure fails to comply. \n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The consultations shall be\ninitiated within forty (40) days of the date on which the request was\nsubmitted. They shall be considered closed within sixty (60) days of the date\non which the request was submitted unless the two Parties agree to pursue them.\nThe information exchanged during the consultations shall remain confidential. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In urgent situations, in\nparticular those involving perishable or seasonal foodstuffs, the consultations\nshall be initiated within fifteen (15) days of the date on which the request\nwas submitted and considered closed within thirty (30) days of the date on\nwhich the request was submitted.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At all stages in the\navoidance and settlement of disputes, the European Union Party shall devote\nspecial attention to the situation and to the particular concerns and interests\nof the States and the West African region.\n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If the consultations are\nnot initiated within the time limits specified in paragraph 3 or paragraph 4 or\nif the consultations are closed without reaching agreement on a mutually\nsatisfactory solution, the applicant shall have the option of invoking the\narbitration procedure provided for in this Agreement.\nArticle 66 \nMediation\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If the consultations do\nnot lead to a mutually satisfactory solution, the Parties may, by amicable\nagreement, resort to a mediator. Unless the Parties decide otherwise, the terms\nof reference of the mediation shall be as set out in the consultation request.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Unless the Parties to the\ndispute agree on a choice of mediator within ten (10) days of the mediation\nrequest being submitted, the Chairperson of the Joint Implementation Committee\nof the EPA or his/her delegate, on being requested to do so by either of the\nParties, shall choose by lot a mediator from among the persons on the list\nreferred to in Article 83 and who are not citizens of the Parties. The\nselection shall be made within twenty (20) days of the mediation request being\nsubmitted, in the presence of a representative from each of the Parties. \n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The mediator shall convene\na meeting of the Parties at the latest thirty (30) days after being appointed.\nThe mediator shall receive the submissions of each Party no later than fifteen\n(15) days before the meeting and give an opinion no later than forty-five (45)\ndays after having been selected. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The mediator\u2019s opinion may\ninclude one or more recommendations on how to resolve the dispute consistent\nwith the provisions referred to in Article 63. The mediator's opinion shall not\nbe binding.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties may agree to\nmodify the time limits referred to in paragraph 3. The mediator may also decide\nto modify these time limits at the request of either Party or on his/her own\ninitiative, depending on the particular difficulties affecting the Party\nconcerned or the complexities of the case.\n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The mediation procedures\nand in particular the information exchanged and the positions adopted by the\nParties during these procedures shall remain confidential.\nCHAPTER 3\nDISPUTE\nSETTLEMENT PROCEDURES \nSection\nI \u2013 Arbitration procedure\nArticle 67 \nInitiation\nof the arbitration procedure \n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where the Parties do not\nsucceed in settling their dispute after having recourse to the consultations\nprovided for in Article 65 or after engaging in the mediation referred to in\nArticle 66, the applicant may request the establishment of an arbitration\npanel.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A request for an\narbitration panel to be formed shall be sent in writing to the respondent and\nthe Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA. In its request, the applicant\nshall describe the specific situation and/or the measure in question and set\nout the reasons why the situation and/or measure violates the provisions of\nthis Agreement.\nArticle 68\nSetting\nup an arbitration panel\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arbitration panel\nshall be composed of three arbitrators.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Within ten (10) days of\nthe request for the establishment of an arbitration panel being submitted to\nthe Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA, the Parties shall consult one\nanother in order to reach an agreement on the composition of the arbitration\npanel. \n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the event that the\nParties are unable to agree on the composition of the arbitration panel within\nthe time frame laid down in paragraph 2, either Party may request the\nChairperson of the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA, or his/her\ndelegate, to select all three members of the panel by lot from the list\nestablished under Article 83: one from among the persons proposed by the\napplicant, one from among the persons proposed by the respondent and the third from\namong those selected by both Parties to chair the meetings. If the Parties have\nagreed on the selection of one or more of the members of the arbitration panel,\nthe remaining member(s) shall be selected according to the same procedure. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Chairperson of the\nJoint Implementation Committee of the EPA or his/her delegate shall select the\narbitrators by lot within five (5) days of receiving the request referred to in\nparagraph 3 in the presence of a representative of each Party. The time and\ndate of the selection shall be communicated to the Parties. No failure by\neither of the Parties to send their representative following an invitation\nshall in any way affect the validity of the selection.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The date on which the\narbitration panel is established shall be the date on which the three\narbitrators are deemed to have been selected. \n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arrangements for\nresponsibility for the arbitration fees are defined in the procedural rules.\nArticle 69\nInterim report by the arbitration panel\nThe arbitration panel shall submit to the\nParties an interim report containing both the descriptive sections and its\nobservations and conclusions, generally within one hundred and twenty (120)\ndays at the latest from the date on which the panel was established. In the\nfifteen (15) days following the presentation of the interim report by the\narbitration panel, each Party shall have the option of submitting remarks in\nwriting to the panel concerning specific aspects of the interim report.\nArticle 70\n\u00a0Arbitration\npanel ruling\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arbitration panel\nshall transmit its ruling to the Parties and the Joint Implementation Committee\nof the EPA at the latest one hundred and fifty (150) days following the\nestablishment of the arbitration panel. If it considers that this time limit\ncannot be respected, the Chairperson of the panel shall inform the Parties and\nthe Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA in writing, giving reasons for\nthe delay and stating the date on which the panel plans to conclude its work.\nThe arbitration ruling should under no circumstances be delivered any later\nthan one hundred and eighty (180) days from the date on which the arbitration\npanel was established.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In urgent situations,\nincluding those involving perishable and seasonal foodstuffs, the panel shall\nendeavour to deliver its ruling within seventy-five (75) days of being\nestablished. Under no circumstance shall it take longer than ninety (90) days\nfrom the date of its establishment. The panel may deliver a preliminary ruling\non whether the case is urgent within ten (10) days of being formed.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Each Party may ask an\narbitration panel to recommend ways in which the respondent could achieve\ncompliance.\nSection\nII \u2013 Achieving compliance\nArticle 71\nCompliance\nwith the arbitration panel ruling\nEach Party shall take all the measures\nnecessary to comply with the arbitration panel ruling. The Parties shall\nendeavour to agree on a time limit for compliance with the ruling. \nArticle 72\nReasonable\ntime limit for compliance\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the latest thirty (30)\ndays after the Parties have been informed of the panel ruling, the respondent\nshall inform the applicant and the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA in\nwriting of the time it will need to achieve compliance (\"reasonable time\nlimit\").\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the event of a\ndisagreement between the Parties regarding what constitutes a reasonable time\nlimit within which to comply with the panel ruling, the applicant shall, within\ntwenty (20) days of the notification provided for in paragraph 1, send a\nwritten request to the panel asking it to determine such a time limit. Such a\nrequest shall be reported simultaneously to the other Party and the Joint\nImplementation Committee of the EPA. The panel shall announce its decision to\nthe Parties and to the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA within thirty\n(30) days of the request being submitted.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arbitration panel\nshall, in determining the reasonable time limit, take into consideration the\nlength of time that it would normally take the respondent to adopt comparable\nlegislative or administrative measures to those identified by the respondent as\nbeing necessary to ensure compliance. Either Party may submit its estimates\nconcerning the time normally needed to adopt such measures. The panel may also\ntake account of demonstrable capacity constraints that might affect the\nadoption of the necessary measures by the respondent.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where the arbitration\npanel or some of its members are unable to attend further meetings, the\nprocedures set out in Article 68 shall be applied. The time limit for delivering\na ruling shall be forty-five (45) days from the date on which the request\nreferred to in paragraph 2 was submitted.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The reasonable time limit\nmay be extended by mutual agreement between the Parties.\nArticle 73\nReview of measures taken to comply with the arbitration panel ruling\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent shall\nnotify the other Party and the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA before\nexpiry of the reasonable time limit of any measures it has taken to comply with\nthe arbitration ruling.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the event of a\ndisagreement between the Parties concerning the compatibility of the measures\nnotified under paragraph 1 with the provisions of this Agreement, the applicant\nmay make a written request for a ruling by the panel on the matter. The request\nshall indicate the specific measures in question and state why they are\nincompatible with the provisions of this Agreement. The panel shall communicate\nits ruling within ninety (90) days of the date on which the request was\nsubmitted. In urgent situations, including cases in which perishable and\nseasonal foodstuffs are in question, the panel shall deliver its ruling within\nforty-five (45) days of the request being submitted.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where the arbitration\npanel or some of its members are unable to attend further meetings, the procedures\nset out in Article 68 shall be applied. The time limit for delivering a ruling\nshall be one hundred and five (105) days from the date on which the request\nreferred to in paragraph 2 was submitted.\nArticle 74\nTemporary remedies in the event of non-compliance\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If the respondent fails to\nreport measures it has taken to comply with the arbitration panel ruling before\nexpiry of the reasonable time limit, or if the arbitration panel rules that the\nmeasures notified under Article 73(1) are not compatible with its obligations\nunder the provisions of Article 71, the respondent shall, if so requested by\nthe applicant, submit to the applicant an offer for temporary compensation. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If the Parties do not\nagree on compensation within thirty (30) days of the reasonable time limit or\nof the ruling by the arbitration panel referred to in Article 73 that the\ncompliance measures that have been taken are not compatible with the provisions\nreferred to in Article 71, the applicant shall be authorised, after having informed\nthe other Party, to take appropriate measures. In taking such measures,\nthe applicant shall endeavour to select measures that as little as possible\naffect the achievement of the objectives of this Agreement. If applicable, the\ntemporary measures shall take account of their impact on the economies of the\nWest African States and should not affect the provision of development aid for\nthe West African region. \n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The European Union Party\nshall show moderation in its requests for compensation or when adopting the\nappropriate measures in accordance with paragraphs 1 and 2 of this Article and\nshall take account of the status of the West African States as developing\ncountries.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appropriate measures\nor compensation shall be temporary and shall cease to be applied when the\nmeasure recognised as being incompatible has been withdrawn or amended in such\na way as to make it comply with the provisions of Article 71 or when the\nParties agree to terminate the dispute settlement procedure.\nArticle 75\nExamination of the compliance measures following the adoption of\nappropriate measures\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent shall\ninform the other Party and the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA of the\nmeasures it has taken to comply with the ruling of the arbitration panel and\nrequest that the measures taken by the applicant shall cease to be applied. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If the Parties do not\nreach an agreement on the compatibility of the notified measures with the\nprovisions of this Agreement within thirty (30) days of the notification being\nsubmitted, the applicant shall make a request in writing for the arbitration\npanel to rule on the matter. Such a request shall be reported simultaneously to\nthe other Party and the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA. The ruling\nof the arbitration panel shall be delivered within forty-five (45) days of\nsubmission of the request and shall be reported to the Parties and the Joint\nImplementation Committee of the EPA. If the arbitration panel rules that the\nmeasures taken are not in conformity with the relevant provisions of this\nAgreement, it shall consider whether it is appropriate for the applicant to\ncontinue to apply the measures taken. If it considers that the measures are not\nin conformity, it shall terminate the application of the measures taken by the\napplicant.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where the arbitration\npanel or some of its members are unable to attend further meetings, the\nprocedures set out in Article 68 shall be applied. The time limit for\ndelivering a ruling shall be sixty (60) days from the date on which the request\nreferred to in paragraph 2 was submitted.\nSection\nIII \u2013 Common and transitional provisions\nArticle 76\nMutually\nsatisfactory solution\nThe Parties may agree on a solution to a\ndispute any time. They shall inform the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA\nof their agreement. The adoption of a mutually satisfactory solution shall\nterminate the procedure.\nArticle 77\nProcedural\nrules\nProcedural rules shall be adopted by the\nJoint Implementation Committee of the EPA within three (3) months of it being\nset up.\nArticle 78\nGeneral\nand technical information\nAt the request of a Party or on its own\ninitiative, the arbitration panel may obtain information from any source,\nincluding the Parties concerned by the dispute, if it deems this to be\nappropriate for the arbitration proceedings. The panel shall also be authorised\nto obtain the opinion of experts if it considers this appropriate. Information\nobtained in this manner must be disclosed to each of the Parties and submitted\nfor their comments.\nArticle 79\nLanguages of submission\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The common working\nlanguages of the Parties for procedures for the prevention and settlement of\ndisputes shall be English, French or Portuguese. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall make\ntheir written or oral submissions in one of these three official languages. \nArticle 80\nRules of interpretation\nThe arbitration panel shall interpret the\nprovisions of this Agreement in accordance with the customary rules of\ninterpretation of public international law, including those set out in the\nVienna Convention on the Law of Treaties. The rulings of the arbitration panel\nshall neither add to nor diminish the rights and obligations set out in this\nAgreement.\nArticle 81\nArbitration panel rulings\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arbitration panel\nshall make its rulings by consensus. Where a ruling cannot be made by\nconsensus, it shall be made by majority vote.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The ruling shall set out\nthe substantive findings, the applicability of the relevant provisions of this\nAgreement and the reasoning underpinning the findings and conclusions reached\nby the arbitration panel. The Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA shall\nmake the arbitration ruling known to the public, unless it decides otherwise. \n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The ruling of the\narbitration panel shall expressly state the way in which account has been taken\nof the flexibility, including the special and differential treatment, provided\nfor in this Agreement if it has been invoked by either of the Parties.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding the\nprovisions of Article 64, the measures taken to comply with the ruling of the\narbitration panel shall specifically apply to the State or States whose\nmeasures have been ruled to be contrary to this Agreement. Consequently, no\nState may be made subject to a penalty if no fault can be attached to it for\nfailure to meet an obligation arising from this Agreement.\nArticle 82\nTransitional\nprovision\nTo take account of the special situation of\n West Africa, the Parties agree that, for a transitional period of ten (10)\nyears following the entry into force of this Agreement, the European Union\nParty shall give full preference to consultation and mediation as ways of\nsettling disputes and shall display moderation in its demands.\nCHAPTER 4\nGENERAL\nPROVISIONS\nArticle 83\nList\nof arbitrators\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Implementation\nCommittee of the EPA shall prepare a list of fifteen (15) arbitrators within\nthree (3) months at the latest of being set up. . Each Party shall appoint one\nthird of the arbitrators. The two Parties shall agree on the choice of the\nremaining third of arbitrators, who shall not be nationals of either Party and\ncould be called upon to chair the arbitration panel. The Joint Implementation\nPanel of the EPA shall ensure that the said list is always complete and that\nthe different specialisms of international trade and economic and trade\npartnership between the two regions are represented.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arbitrators shall have\nspecialised knowledge or experience of law and international trade. They shall\nbe independent, act individually and not under the instructions of any\norganisation or government, shall not be affiliated to the administration of\neither Party, and shall observe the Code of Conduct appended to the Procedural\nRules.\nArticle 84\nLinks with the WTO obligations\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arbitration bodies set\nup under this Agreement shall not be authorised to rule on disputes relating to\nthe rights and obligations of each Party pursuant to the Agreement establishing\nthe World Trade Organisation (WTO). \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Recourse to the dispute\nsettlement provisions of this Agreement shall be without prejudice to any\naction in connection with the WTO, including dispute settlement action.\nHowever, when a Party has initiated a dispute settlement procedure with regard\nto a given measure either under Article 67(1) of this Agreement or under the\nWTO Agreement, it may not initiate a dispute settlement procedure for the same\nmeasure with the other forum before concluding the first procedure. For\nthe purposes of this paragraph, a Party shall be considered to have initiated a\ndispute settlement procedure under the WTO Agreement once it has requested the\nestablishment of a panel pursuant to Article 6 of the WTO Dispute Settlement\nUnderstanding.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This Agreement cannot\nprevent a Party from applying the suspension of obligations authorised by the\nWTO Dispute Settlement Body. The WTO Agreement cannot prevent the Parties from\nsuspending the benefits granted under this Agreement.\nArticle 85\nTime limits \n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 All the limitation periods\nlaid down in this Part, including the times by which the arbitration panels\nmust deliver their rulings, shall be expressed in calendar days from the day\nfollowing the act or fact to which it refers. If the last day is a non-working\nday, the time limit shall be deemed to fall on the next working day. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Any time limit provided\nfor in this Part of the Agreement may be extended by mutual agreement between\nthe Parties. \nArticle 86\nCooperation \nThe Parties\nagree to cooperate, including financially, in accordance with the provisions\nlaid down in Part III, with regard to legal aid and in particular with regard\nto building up capacities in order to make possible the use by the West Africa\nParty of the dispute settlement mechanism provided for in this Agreement.\nPART V\nGENERAL\nEXCEPTIONS\nArticle 87 \nGeneral\nexception clause\nSubject to the\nrequirement that such measures are not applied in a manner that would\nconstitute a means of arbitrary or unjustifiable discrimination between the\nParties where like conditions prevail, or a disguised restriction on trade in\ngoods or services or on establishment, nothing in this Agreement shall be construed\nto prevent the adoption or application by either Party of measures:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 necessary to protect public\nmorals, order or safety;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 necessary to protect the life or\nhealth of humans, animals or plants;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 necessary to secure compliance\nwith laws or regulations that are not inconsistent with the provisions of this\nAgreement including those relating to:\ni)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the prevention of deceptive and\nfraudulent practices or to deal with the effects of a default on contractual\npayments;\nii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 protection of the privacy of individuals\nin relation to the processing and dissemination of personal data and the\nprotection of confidentiality of individual records and accounts;\niii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 security;\n(iv)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 customs enforcement; or\n(v)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the protection of intellectual\nproperty rights;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 relating to the import or export\nof gold or silver;\ne)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 concerning the protection of\nnational treasures of artistic, historic or archaeological value;\nf)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 relating to the conservation of\nnon-renewable natural resources if such measures imply restrictions on domestic\nproduction or consumption of goods, domestic supply or consumption of services\nor domestic investors;\ng)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 relating to the products of\nprison labour; \nh)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 essential for the acquisition or\ndistribution of products of which there is a general or local scarcity.\nHowever, these measures should be compatible with the principle that the\nParties are entitled to a fair share of the international supply of the\nproducts in question. All the measures referred to above that are incompatible\nwith the other provisions of this Agreement shall be eliminated as soon as the\ncircumstances giving rise to them have ceased to exist.\nArticle 88 \nSecurity\nexceptions\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nothing in this Agreement\nshall be construed:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 as requiring either Party to furnish\nany information, the disclosure of which it considers contrary to its essential\nsecurity interests;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 as preventing the Parties from taking\nany action deemed necessary for the protection of their essential security\ninterests:\ni)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 relating to fissile or fissionable\nmaterials or the materials from which they are derived;\nii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 relating to economic activities\ncarried out directly or indirectly for the purpose of supplying or provisioning\na military establishment;\niii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 connected with the production of or\ntrade in arms, munitions and war material;\n(iv)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 relating to government contracts\nessential for national security or for national defence purposes;\n(v)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 taken in time of war or other\nemergency in international relations;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 as preventing the Parties from taking\nany action in order to honour their obligations for the purpose of maintaining\ninternational peace and security. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Implementation\nCommittee of the EPA shall be informed to the fullest extent possible of\nmeasures taken under paragraph 1(b) and (c) and of their termination dates.\nArticle 89 \nBalance\nof payments difficulties\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where a Party is in\nserious balance of payments and external financial difficulties, or under\nthreat thereof, it may take or maintain restrictive measures with regard to\ntrade in goods and in services and with regard to payments and capital\nmovements, including measures relating to direct investment. \n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Parties shall\nendeavour, as far as possible, to avoid the application of the restrictive\nmeasures referred to in paragraph 1.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Restrictive measures adopted\nor maintained under this Article shall be non-discriminatory and of limited\nduration and shall not go beyond what is necessary to remedy the difficulties\nrelating to the balance of payments and external financial situation. They\nshould be in accordance with the conditions established in the WTO Agreements\nand consistent with the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary\nFund, as applicable. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Any Party that is\nmaintaining or has taken restrictive measures or is modifying such measures\nshall immediately inform the other Parties and as soon as possible submit a\nschedule for them to be dismantled. \n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Consultation shall be\ncarried out without delay in the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA. The\npurpose of such consultation shall be to assess the balance of payments\nsituation of the Party or Parties concerned and the restrictions adopted or\nmaintained under this Article, taking into account, inter alia, such factors\nas: \na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the nature and extent of the balance\nof payments difficulties and the external financial difficulties;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the external economic and trade\nenvironment; \nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 alternative corrective measures that\nmay be available. \n6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The extent to which\nrestrictive measures comply with paragraphs 3 and 4 of this Article shall be\nexamined during the consultation. Findings of statistical or other facts\npresented by the International Monetary Fund relating to foreign exchange,\nmonetary reserves and balance of payments shall be accepted and conclusions\nshall be based on the assessment by the International Monetary Fund of the\nbalance of payments and the external financial situation of the Party in\nquestion.\nArticle 90 \nTaxation\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nothing in this Agreement\nor any accommodation or arrangement adopted in connection with it shall be\nconstrued as preventing the Parties from distinguishing, in the application of\nthe relevant provisions of their fiscal legislation, between taxpayers who are\nnot in the same situation, in particular with regard to their place of\nresidence or with regard to the place where their capital is invested.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nothing in this Agreement\nor any accommodation or arrangement adopted under this Agreement shall be\nconstrued as preventing the adoption or enforcement of any measure aimed at\npreventing tax fraud or evasion under agreements intended to avoid double\ntaxation or other tax arrangements or domestic fiscal legislation.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nothing in this Agreement\nshall affect the rights and obligations of the Parties under any tax\nconvention. In the event of any inconsistency between this Agreement and such a\nconvention, the convention shall prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.\nPART\nVI\nINSTITUTIONAL\nPROVISIONS\nArticle 91\nJoint bodies of the EPA\nAn institutional\nframework has been set up for the supervision and implementation of the\nEconomic Partnership Agreement between the West Africa Party and the European\nUnion Party, including the following bodies:\na)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa - European Union EPA ;\nb)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Implementation\nCommittee of the West Africa - European Union EPA;\nc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint West Africa - European\nUnion Parliamentary Committee;\nd)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint West Africa-European\nUnion Consultative Committee;\nArticle 92\nJoint Council of the West Africa - European Union EPA \n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA shall be responsible for supervising the implementation of\nthis Agreement. It shall meet at ministerial level.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Without prejudice to the\nfunctions of the ACP-EU Council of Ministers as defined in Article 15 of the\nCotonou Agreement, the Joint Council of the West Africa - European Union EPA\nshall ensure the operation of the institutional architecture of this Agreement\nand its implementation and shall monitor the achievement of its objectives. It\nshall also examine any major issue arising within the framework of this\nAgreement, as well as any other bilateral, multilateral or international\nquestion of common interest affecting this economic and trade partnership\nbetween the Parties.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA shall also examine the proposals and recommendations of\nthe Parties with regard to the review of this Agreement in line with the\nprocedures set out in Article 111. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA shall meet once every two (2) years. It may also meet in\nextraordinary sessions if circumstances so require.\nArticle 93 \nComposition and rules of procedure\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the\nWest Africa - European Union EPA shall be composed, on the one hand, of Members\nof the Council of the European Union and Members of the European Commission\nand, on the other hand, of Members of the Ministerial Monitoring Committee of\nthe West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA and the Presidents of the ECOWAS and UEMOA\nCommissions.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA shall adopt its rules of procedure;\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Presidency of the\nJoint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA shall be held in turn by\na representative of the European Union Party and by a representative of the\nWest Africa Party in accordance with the conditions laid down by its rules of\nprocedure. \n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa - European Union EPA shall submit periodic reports on the operation of this\nAgreement to the Council of Ministers established in accordance with Article 15\nof the Cotonou Agreement.\n5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Members of the Joint\nCouncil of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA may arrange to be represented\nin accordance with the conditions laid down in its rules of procedure.\nArticle 94 \nDecision-making powers and procedures\n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In order to attain the\nobjectives of this Agreement, the Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European\nUnion EPA shall have the power to take decisions in respect of the matters\ncovered by the Agreement.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The decisions taken shall\nbe binding on the Parties, which shall take any measures necessary to apply\nthem in accordance with their domestic legal systems.\n3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA may also make recommendations.\n4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA shall adopt its decisions and recommendations by mutual\nagreement between the Parties.\nArticle 95 \nJoint Implementation Committee of the West Africa\u2013 European Union\nEPA \n1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the performance of its\nmission, the Joint Council of the West Africa \u2013 European Union EPA shall be\nassisted by the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA, comprising senior\nofficials or their representatives duly appointed by the Parties. Either Party\nmay submit to the Joint Implementation Committee of the EPA any question\nconcerning the application of the Agreement or the pursuit of its objectives.\n2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Joint Council of the\nEPA shall establish and adopt the rules of procedure of the Joint\nImplementation Committee of the EPA.
